reading.title: What's the Big Message?
reading.content: The theme is the deeper message or lesson in a story. In nonfiction, it's called the central idea — what the text is mostly about.

reading.title: Prove It with the Text
reading.content: Strong readers back up their answers with exact lines or paraphrases from the text to support their thinking.

reading.title: How Characters Grow
reading.content: Characters in literature often change due to challenges they face. Analyzing this helps us understand the story’s message.

reading.title: Whose Eyes Are We Seeing Through?
reading.content: First-person, third-person limited, and omniscient narrators all affect how a story is told and what we learn about characters.

reading.title: More Than Just the Words
reading.content: Authors use similes, metaphors, personification, and hyperbole to create vivid images and deeper meaning.

reading.title: Feeling the Text
reading.content: Tone is the author’s attitude. Mood is how the text makes the reader feel. Both are created through word choice and detail.

reading.title: What's Similar? What's Different?
reading.content: You may compare two poems, speeches, or stories by examining their structure, message, or style.

reading.title: Why Did the Author Write This?
reading.content: Authors write to persuade, inform, or entertain. Their word choice, structure, and tone reveal their goals.

reading.title: How the Text is Built
reading.content: Nonfiction can be organized by cause/effect, problem/solution, compare/contrast, or chronological order.

reading.title: Is That a Strong Argument?
reading.content: Good arguments have a clear claim, evidence, and reasoning. Watch out for weak logic or emotional manipulation.

reading.title: Guess the Word
reading.content: You can figure out tough words using context clues from the sentence or paragraph around them.

reading.title: Simple, Compound, Complex
reading.content: A sentence can be short or long, but every sentence needs a subject and a verb. Learn how to vary sentence structure in writing.

reading.title: Flowing Smoothly
reading.content: Transition words like 'however', 'in contrast', and 'as a result' help connect ideas clearly.

reading.title: Explaining with Evidence
reading.content: Informative writing shares facts and ideas with a clear structure: intro, body paragraphs with evidence, and a conclusion.

reading.title: Make Your Case
reading.content: Argument writing needs a strong claim, organized reasoning, and supporting evidence. Counterarguments strengthen your position.

reading.title: Big Ideas Across Texts
reading.content: Complex literary texts often explore multiple themes like identity, justice, or freedom. Analyze how they develop over time and interact.

reading.title: How Authors Leave Their Mark
reading.content: An author's style includes diction, syntax, and tone. Voice reflects their unique perspective and emotional effect on the reader.

reading.title: Logos, Pathos, and Ethos
reading.content: Rhetorical appeals are strategies used to persuade: logic (logos), emotion (pathos), and credibility (ethos).

reading.title: Criticism with Humor
reading.content: Satire uses humor, irony, and exaggeration to expose flaws in society or individuals. Irony adds layers of meaning.

reading.title: Word Choice and Sentence Structure
reading.content: Authors deliberately choose words (diction) and sentence arrangements (syntax) to affect tone and meaning.

reading.title: Two Voices, One Theme
reading.content: Compare how different authors approach similar topics using different structures, styles, or cultural perspectives.

reading.title: What Makes an Argument Effective?
reading.content: An effective argument presents a claim, supports it with clear reasoning and evidence, and addresses counterarguments.

reading.title: When Logic Fails
reading.content: Writers may use flawed reasoning or show bias. Spot common fallacies like false cause, ad hominem, and slippery slope.

reading.title: Ideas that Shaped a Nation
reading.content: Analyze key documents like the Declaration of Independence, speeches by Lincoln and King, and the Constitution for purpose and rhetoric.

reading.title: Building Your Argument
reading.content: Research writing requires strong claims, credible sources, MLA/APA citation, and a clear organizational structure.

reading.title: Putting Sources Together
reading.content: Synthesis means combining ideas from multiple texts to support a new idea or answer a complex question.

reading.title: Think Fast, Write Clearly
reading.content: Timed writing demands quick planning, a focused thesis, well-organized paragraphs, and strong evidence under pressure.

reading.title: The Subtle Power of Language
reading.content: Tone is how the author feels. Nuance is the slight differences in meaning that make text deeper and more sophisticated.

reading.title: Mastering Sentence Variety
reading.content: Varying sentence structure improves flow and emphasis. Use clauses, punctuation, and parallel structure skillfully.

reading.title: Writing About You, With Depth
reading.content: Narratives with personal insight help reveal identity and values. Use vivid detail, pacing, and emotional honesty.

reading.content: Research writing requires strong claims, credible sources, MLA/APA citation, and a clear organizational structure.

reading.title: Putting Sources Together
reading.content: Synthesis means combining ideas from multiple texts to support a new idea or answer a complex question.

reading.title: Think Fast, Write Clearly
reading.content: Timed writing demands quick planning, a focused thesis, well-organized paragraphs, and strong evidence under pressure.

reading.title: The Subtle Power of Language
reading.content: Tone is how the author feels. Nuance is the slight differences in meaning that make text deeper and more sophisticated.

reading.title: Mastering Sentence Variety
reading.content: Varying sentence structure improves flow and emphasis. Use clauses, punctuation, and parallel structure skillfully.

reading.title: Writing About You, With Depth
reading.content: Narratives with personal insight help reveal identity and values. Use vivid detail, pacing, and emotional honesty.

reading.title: Big Ideas Across Texts
reading.content: Complex literary texts often explore multiple themes like identity, justice, or freedom. Analyze how they develop over time and interact.

reading.title: How Authors Leave Their Mark
reading.content: An author's style includes diction, syntax, and tone. Voice reflects their unique perspective and emotional effect on the reader.

reading.title: Logos, Pathos, and Ethos
reading.content: Rhetorical appeals are strategies used to persuade: logic (logos), emotion (pathos), and credibility (ethos).

reading.title: Criticism with Humor
reading.content: Satire uses humor, irony, and exaggeration to expose flaws in society or individuals. Irony adds layers of meaning.

reading.title: Word Choice and Sentence Structure
reading.content: Authors deliberately choose words (diction) and sentence arrangements (syntax) to affect tone and meaning.

reading.title: Two Voices, One Theme
reading.content: Compare how different authors approach similar topics using different structures, styles, or cultural perspectives.

reading.title: What Makes an Argument Effective?
reading.content: An effective argument presents a claim, supports it with clear reasoning and evidence, and addresses counterarguments.

reading.title: When Logic Fails
reading.content: Writers may use flawed reasoning or show bias. Spot common fallacies like false cause, ad hominem, and slippery slope.

reading.title: Ideas that Shaped a Nation
reading.content: Analyze key documents like the Declaration of Independence, speeches by Lincoln and King, and the Constitution for purpose and rhetoric.
